11001: The vowels आ, ऐ, and औ are called vṛddhi. These are the strengthened vowel grades: अ strengthens to आ, इ/ई to ऐ, and उ/ऊ to औ.
11002: The vowels अ, ए, and ओ are called guṇa. These are the medium vowel grades: इ/ई becomes ए, उ/ऊ becomes ओ. The vowel अ serves as both base and guṇa.
11003: When guṇa or vṛddhi is prescribed without specifying where, the substitution applies to an इक् vowel (इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ) in the base.
11004: Guṇa and vṛddhi do not apply when an ārdhadhātuka suffix causes part of the root to be deleted.
11005: Guṇa and vṛddhi are also blocked before suffixes marked with क्, ङ्, or ग् as an indicatory letter.
11006: The roots दीधीङ्, वेवीङ्, and the augment इट् do not undergo guṇa or vṛddhi.
11007: Two or more consonants pronounced together without an intervening vowel form a saṃyoga (consonant cluster).
11008: A sound pronounced through both mouth and nose is called anunāsika (nasalized).
11009: Sounds with the same place of articulation and the same articulatory effort are called savarṇa (homogeneous).
11010: A vowel and a consonant are never savarṇa of each other.
11011: Dual endings in ई, ऊ, or ए are called pragṛhya (exempt from sandhi).
11012: Forms of अदस् ending in मात् are pragṛhya.
11014: Single-vowel particles except आङ् are pragṛhya.
11015: Particles ending in ओ are pragṛhya.
11016: According to Śākalya, vocative singular forms ending in ओ before इति are optionally pragṛhya (in non-Vedic usage).
11019: Words ending in ई or ऊ with locative meaning are pragṛhya.
11020: The roots दा and धा, and roots called घु (except दाप् and दैप्), receive special treatment.
11021: In a single-sound item, that sound counts as both first and last.
11022: The suffixes तरप् and तमप् are called घ.
11023: The words बहु and गण, and words ending in वतुप् or डति, are called saṅkhyā (numerals).
11024: Saṅkhyā words ending in ष् or न् are also called षट्.
11025: Words ending in डति are also called षट्.
11026: The suffixes क्त and क्तवतु are called niṣṭhā (past passive participle markers).
11027: Words in the sarvādi class are called sarvanāman (pronouns).
11028: In a directional bahuvrīhi compound, sarvādi words are optionally treated as pronouns.
11029: In other bahuvrīhi compounds, sarvādi words are not treated as pronouns.
11030: In tatpuruṣa compounds with instrumental relation, sarvādi words are not pronouns.
11031: In dvandva compounds, sarvādi words are not pronouns.
11032: Before the ending जस्, sarvādi words are optionally treated as pronouns.
11033: The words प्रथम, चरम, तय, अल्प, अर्ध, कतिपय, and नेम are optionally pronouns before जस्.
11034: The words पूर्व, पर, अवर, दक्षिण, उत्तर, अपर, and अधर are optionally pronouns before जस् when denoting position (not as proper names).
11035: The word स्व is optionally a pronoun before जस् when not meaning 'kinsmen' or 'wealth'.
11036: The word अन्तर is optionally a pronoun before जस् when meaning 'outside' or 'undergarment'.
11037: Words in the svarādi class and particles (nipāta) are indeclinables (avyaya).
11038: A taddhita derivative that cannot take all case endings is an indeclinable.
11039: Kṛt derivatives ending in म् or an एच् vowel are indeclinables.
11040: Words ending in क्त्वा, तोसुन्, or कसुन् are indeclinables.
11042: The ending शि is called sarvanāmasthāna.
11043: The endings सु, औ, जस्, अम्, and औट् are sarvanāmasthāna when attached to non-neuter stems.
11044: The word विभाषा means 'optionally'—the rule may or may not apply.
11045: An इक् vowel (इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ) that replaces a यण् semivowel is called samprasāraṇa.
11046: An augment marked ट् is prefixed; one marked क् is suffixed.
11047: An augment marked म् is inserted after the last vowel.
11048: When an एच् vowel (ए, ओ, ऐ, औ) is shortened, it becomes the corresponding इक् vowel (इ or उ).
11049: A genitive in a rule indicates the substitute's target (sthānin) when no other relationship is clear.
11050: Among possible substitutes, the one most similar to the original is chosen.
11051: When ऋ is replaced by अण् (अ, र्), the result is always followed by र् (rapara).
11052: A substitute prescribed in the genitive replaces only the last sound of the original.
11053: A substitute also replaces the last sound when prescribed with ङित् marking.
11054: A substitute replaces the first sound of what follows when so specified.
11055: A multi-sound substitute marked with श् replaces the entire original.
11056: A substitute behaves like the original for rules—except those concerning single sounds.
11057: For rules that look at what precedes, the substitute stands in for the original vowel.
11058: But the substitute doesn't stand in for: word-final position, reduplication, र/ए/य-insertion, elision, accent, savarṇa, anusvāra, lengthening, or जश्/चर् changes.
11059: In reduplication, it doesn't stand in when a vowel follows.
11060: Disappearance of a sound is called lopa (elision).
11061: For suffixes, there are three types of elision: लुक्, श्लु, and लुप्.
11062: When a suffix is elided, the base still behaves as if the suffix were present.
11063: But not when the elision is by लुक्—then suffix-triggered changes don't apply to the base.
11064: The last vowel and everything after it is called टि.
11065: The sound before the last vowel is called upadhā (penultimate).
11066: When a rule says 'of that' (तस्मिन्), the operation applies to what precedes.
11067: When a rule says 'after that' (तस्मात्), the operation applies to what follows.
11068: A word in a rule refers to itself (svarūpa)—unless it's a technical term (saṃjñā).
11069: A vowel marked with अण् or उदित् stands for itself and all its homogeneous sounds—unless it's a suffix.
11070: A vowel marked with त् (tapara) refers only to that exact prosodic length.
11071: The first sound together with the last marker forms a pratyāhāra (abbreviation for a sound class).
11072: A rule about X applies to items ending in X.
11073: A stem whose first vowel is vṛddhi is called vṛddha.
11074: The त्यद्-class words (त्यद्, तद्, etc.) are also vṛddha.
11075: In the eastern region, एङ् vowels (ए, ओ) count as vṛddhi.
12001: All suffixes after गा and the कुटादि roots are ङित्, except those marked with ञ् or ण्.
12002: After विज्, suffixes that take the इट् augment are treated as ङित्.
12003: After ऊर्णु, suffixes with इट् are optionally ङित्.
12004: Sārvadhātuka suffixes without प् marking are treated as ङित्.
12005: After roots without a consonant cluster, लिट् suffixes are कित्.
12006: After इन्धि and भू, लिट् suffixes are also कित्.
12007: After मृड्, मृद्, गुध्, कुष्, क्लिश्, वद्, and वस्, the suffix क्त्वा is कित्.
12008: After रुद्, विद्, मुष्, ग्रह्, स्वप्, and प्रच्छ्, both क्त्वा and सन् are कित्.
12009: After a root with इक् penultimate followed by झल्, the झलादि सन् is कित्.
12010: After a consonant-final root with इक् penultimate, the झलादि सन् is कित्.
12011: In ātmanepada, the झलादि suffixes of लिङ् and सिच् are कित् after roots with इक् penultimate.
12012: After roots ending in ऋ, the same affixes are कित्.
12013: After गम्, these affixes are optionally कित्.
12014: After हन्, सिच् in ātmanepada is कित्.
12015: When यम् means 'to restrain', सिच् in ātmanepada is कित्.
12016: When यम् means 'to raise', सिच् is optionally कित्.
12017: After स्था and घु-roots, the आ becomes इ before सिच्, which is then कित्.
12018: When क्त्वा takes इट्, it is not कित्.
12019: After शी, स्विद्, मिद्, क्ष्विद्, and धृष्, the सेट् niṣṭhā is not कित्.
12020: After मृष् meaning 'to endure', सेट् niṣṭhā is not कित्.
12021: After roots with उ as penultimate, सेट् niṣṭhā is optionally not कित् in भाव and आदिकर्मन् meanings.
12022: After पू, both सेट् niṣṭhā and सेट् क्त्वा are not कित्.
12023: After roots with penultimate nasal ending in थ् or फ्, सेट् क्त्वा is optionally कित्.
12024: After वञ्च्, लुञ्च्, and ऋत्, सेट् क्त्वा is optionally कित्.
12025: According to Kāśyapa, after तृष्, मृष्, and कृश्, सेट् क्त्वा is optionally कित्.
12026: After roots ending in रल् with इ/उ penultimate and beginning with a consonant, सेट् क्त्वा and सन् are optionally कित्.
12027: A vowel with one mātrā is called hrasva (short), with two is dīrgha (long), with three is pluta (prolonged).
12028: When hrasva, dīrgha, or pluta is prescribed, it replaces a vowel, not a consonant.
12029: A vowel perceived as high-pitched is called udātta (acute).
12030: A vowel perceived as low-pitched is called anudātta (grave).
12031: A vowel combining udātta and anudātta tones is called svarita (circumflex).
12032: The first half-mātrā of a svarita vowel is udātta.
12033: In calling from a distance, the tone is called ekaśruti (monotone).
12034: In sacrificial rites, ekaśruti is used, except in japa, nyūṅkha, and sāma chanting.
12035: In pronouncing वषट्, the raised tone is optional.
12036: In Vedic recitation, ekaśruti is optional.
12037: In subrahmanyā hymns, there is no ekaśruti; svarita becomes udātta.
12038: In those hymns, देव and ब्राह्मण take anudātta.
12039: After svarita in connected speech, anudātta becomes ekaśruti.
12040: An anudātta before udātta or svarita becomes sannatara (extra-low).
12041: A single-letter suffix is called apṛkta.
12042: A tatpuruṣa where both members are in the same case is called karmadhāraya.
12043: In compound rules, the word in the nominative is called upasarjana (subordinate).
12044: A word with a fixed case is also upasarjana, but need not come first.
12045: A meaningful form that is neither a root nor a suffix is called prātipadika (stem).
12046: Forms with kṛt or taddhita suffixes, or compounds, are also prātipadika.
12047: In the neuter, the final vowel of a prātipadika is shortened.
12048: The final vowel of गो or a feminine stem is shortened when it is upasarjana.
12049: When a taddhita is लुक्-elided, the feminine suffix of the upasarjana is also elided.
12050: For गोणी, the feminine suffix becomes short इ (not elided) when taddhita is लुक्-elided.
12051: When a taddhita is लुप्-elided, the derived word keeps the gender and number of the original.
12052: Adjectives agree in gender and number with लुप्-derived words, unless the latter are jāti (class) words.
12053: Gender and number agreement is conventional (saṃjñā), not requiring explicit teaching.
12054: Rules about लुप्-elision need not be taught—the etymological meaning is not current.
12055: If etymological meaning were authoritative, words should vanish when that meaning is absent.
12056: Meaning depends on usage, not on the principal member of a compound or on the suffix.
12057: Similarly, defining tense (kāla) and subordination (upasarjana) by rules is unnecessary.
12058: For class-nouns (jāti), the plural may optionally denote the singular.
12059: The plural of अस्मद् (I/we) may optionally be used for singular or dual meaning.
12060: The dual of the stars फाल्गुनी and प्रोष्ठपदा may optionally be plural.
12061: In the Vedas, the star पुनर्वसू may optionally take singular form with dual meaning.
12062: In the Vedas, the star विशाखा may optionally be singular (though normally dual).
12063: In dvandva compounds of तिष्य and पुनर्वसू (stars), the dual replaces the plural.
12064: When words of the same form and case are combined, only one is retained (ekaśeṣa).
12065: A gotra word is retained over a yuvan word when they differ only in suffix.
12066: A feminine gotra word, when combined with a yuvan, is retained and treated as masculine.
12067: A masculine word is retained when combined with a feminine differing only in gender suffix.
12068: भ्रातृ is retained over स्वसृ; पुत्र is retained over दुहितृ.
12069: A neuter word is optionally retained, treated as singular, when combined with other genders.
12070: पितृ is optionally retained when combined with मातृ.
12071: श्वशुर is optionally retained when combined with श्वश्रू.
12072: The pronouns त्यद्, etc. are always retained (ekaśeṣa) when combined with other words.
12073: For groups of domestic animals (not young), the feminine word is retained.
13001: Words like भू that denote action are called dhātu (verbal root).
13002: In original enunciation (upadeśa), nasalized vowels are indicatory (it).
13003: In upadeśa, the final consonant of roots and affixes is indicatory.
13004: In vibhakti (case/personal endings), final त-class consonants, स्, and म् are not indicatory.
13005: Initial ञि, टु, and डु are indicatory.
13006: The initial ष् of an affix is indicatory.
13007: Initial palatals and cerebrals of an affix are indicatory.
13008: In affixes (except taddhita), initial ल्, श्, and gutturals (क्, ख्, ग्, घ्, ङ्) are indicatory.
13009: Indicatory letters (it) are elided—they mark grammatical properties but don't appear in the final form.
13010: When substitutes and targets are equal in number, they correspond in order: first to first, second to second.
13011: A sūtra with svarita accent marks an adhikāra (governing rule) that extends over subsequent sūtras.
13012: After roots with anudātta-marked vowels or ङ् as indicatory, ātmanepada endings are used.
13013: Ātmanepada replaces ल when the verb denotes action (bhāva) or object (karma), not agent.
13014: When reciprocal action is expressed, ātmanepada is used even for the agent.
13015: But for verbs of motion or injury, parasmaipada is used even with reciprocal meaning.
13016: When इतरेतर or अन्योन्य ('each other') is the upapada, parasmaipada is used despite reciprocity.
13017: After विश् preceded by नि, ātmanepada is used: निविशते 'he enters'.
13018: After क्री preceded by परि, वि, or अव, ātmanepada is used even when the fruit doesn't accrue to the agent.
13019: After जि preceded by वि or परा, ātmanepada is used: विजयते 'he conquers'.
13020: After दा preceded by आ, ātmanepada is used—except when meaning 'to open the mouth'.
13021: After क्रीड् preceded by अनु, सम्, परि, or आ, ātmanepada is used: आक्रीडते 'he plays'.
13022: After स्था preceded by सम्, अव, प्र, or वि, ātmanepada is used: प्रतिष्ठते 'he sets forth'.
13023: After स्था meaning 'to indicate intentions' or 'to arbitrate', ātmanepada is used.
13024: After स्था preceded by उद्, ātmanepada is used—except when meaning 'to rise from a seat'.
13025: After स्था preceded by उप meaning 'to worship', ātmanepada is used: उपतिष्ठते 'he worships'.
13026: After स्था preceded by उप, when intransitive (attending at meal time), ātmanepada is used.
13027: After तप् preceded by उद् or वि, when intransitive, ātmanepada is used: वितपते 'he shines'.
13028: After यम् or हन् preceded by आ, when intransitive, ātmanepada is used: आयच्छते 'it spreads'.
13029: After गम्, ऋच्छ्, प्रच्छ्, स्वर्, ऋ, श्रु, and विद् preceded by सम्, when intransitive, ātmanepada is used.
13030: After ह्वे preceded by नि, सम्, उप, or वि, ātmanepada is used: उपह्वयते 'he calls'.
13031: After ह्वे preceded by आ meaning 'to challenge', ātmanepada is used: आह्वयते 'he challenges'.
13032: After कृ meaning 'to divulge, revile, serve, use violence, cause change, recite, or work toward a goal', ātmanepada is used.
13033: After कृ preceded by अधि meaning 'to overcome', ātmanepada is used: अधिचक्रे 'he overcame'.
13034: After कृ preceded by वि, when the object is sound, ātmanepada is used: विकुरुते स्वरान् 'he makes sounds'.
13035: After कृ preceded by वि, when intransitive, ātmanepada is used: विकुर्वन्ते 'they move gracefully'.
13036: After नी meaning 'to guide, lift up, make a teacher, determine truth, employ, pay debt, or give in charity', ātmanepada is used.
13037: After नी governing an incorporeal object residing in the agent, ātmanepada is used: क्रोधं विनयते 'he subdues his anger'.
13038: After क्रम् meaning 'continuity, energy, or development', ātmanepada is used.
13039: After क्रम् preceded by उप or पर in those senses, ātmanepada is used: उपक्रमते 'he commences'.
13040: After क्रम् preceded by आ meaning 'rising of a luminary', ātmanepada is used: आक्रमते सूर्यः 'the sun rises'.
13041: After क्रम् preceded by वि meaning 'pacing', ātmanepada is used: विक्रमते 'the horse paces'.
13042: After क्रम् preceded by प्र or उप meaning 'to begin', ātmanepada is used: प्रक्रमते भोक्तुम् 'he begins to eat'.
13043: Without any upasarga, क्रम् optionally takes ātmanepada: क्रमते or क्रामति 'he goes'.
13044: After ज्ञा meaning 'to deny', ātmanepada is used: अपजानीते 'he denies'.
13045: After ज्ञा when intransitive (engaging in sacrifice), ātmanepada is used: सर्पिषो जानीते 'he engages with ghee'.
13046: After ज्ञा preceded by सम् or प्रति, ātmanepada is used—except when meaning 'remembering with regret'.
13047: After वद् meaning 'to show brilliance, pacify, know, strive, disagree, or flatter', ātmanepada is used.
13048: After वद् meaning 'articulate speech together', ātmanepada is used: संप्रवदन्ते 'they are speaking'.
13049: After वद् preceded by अनु, when intransitive and meaning 'to echo', ātmanepada is used: अनुवदते 'he echoes'.
13050: After वद् meaning 'to contradict each other', ātmanepada is optional: विप्रवदन्ते or विप्रवदन्ति 'they dispute'.
13051: After गॄ preceded by अव, ātmanepada is used: अवगिरते 'he swallows'.
13052: After गॄ preceded by सम् meaning 'to promise', ātmanepada is used: संगिरते 'he promises'.
13053: After चर् preceded by उद् when intransitive, ātmanepada is used: उच्चरते 'he strays'.
13054: After चर् preceded by सम् when connected with an instrumental, ātmanepada is used: अश्वेन संचरते 'he rides'.
13055: After दा preceded by सम् with an instrumental having dative sense (immoral conduct implied), ātmanepada is used.
13056: After यम् preceded by उप meaning 'to espouse', ātmanepada is used: भार्यामुपयच्छते 'he marries'.
13057: Desideratives of ज्ञा, श्रु, स्मृ, and दृश् take ātmanepada: जिज्ञासते 'he wishes to know'.
13058: But the desiderative of ज्ञा preceded by अनु takes parasmaipada: अनुजिज्ञासति.
13059: Desideratives of श्रु preceded by प्रति or आ take parasmaipada: प्रतिशुश्रूषति.
13060: After शद् before शित् affixes, ātmanepada is used: शीयते 'he decays'.
13061: After मृ before शित्, लुङ्, and लिङ् affixes, ātmanepada is used: म्रियते 'he dies', अमृत 'he died'.
13062: A desiderative takes the same pada as its primitive: if आस्ते, then असिसिषते 'he wishes to sit'.
13063: In periphrastic perfect, the auxiliary कृ takes the pada of the main verb: एधांचक्रे 'he prospered'.
13064: After युज् preceded by प्र or उप (not for sacrificial vessels), ātmanepada is used: प्रयुङ्क्ते 'he employs'.
13065: After क्ष्णु preceded by सम्, ātmanepada is used: संक्ष्णुते 'he whets'.
13066: After भुज् except in the sense of 'protecting', ātmanepada is used: भुङ्क्ते 'he eats'.
13067: Causatives take ātmanepada when the non-causal object becomes the causal agent: आरोहयते हस्ती 'the elephant causes itself to be mounted'.
13068: Causatives of भी and स्मि take ātmanepada when fear/wonder is directly caused: भीषयते 'he frightens'.
13069: Causatives of गृध् and वञ्च् meaning 'to deceive' take ātmanepada: वञ्चयते 'he deceives'.
13070: Causatives of ली meaning 'to respect, subdue, or deceive' take ātmanepada: उल्लापयते 'he subdues'.
13071: The causative of कृ with मिथ्या meaning 'repeated wrong utterance' takes ātmanepada: मिथ्या कारयते.
13072: After svarita-marked or ञित् roots, ātmanepada is used when the fruit accrues to the agent: यजते 'he sacrifices for himself'.
13073: After वद् preceded by अप, ātmanepada is used when fruit accrues to agent: अपवदते 'he forsakes'.
13074: Causatives take ātmanepada when the fruit accrues to the agent: कटं कारयते 'he has a mat made for himself'.
13075: After यम् preceded by सम्, उद्, or आ (not referring to a book), ātmanepada is used when fruit accrues to agent.
13076: After ज्ञा without upasarga, ātmanepada is used when fruit accrues to agent: गां जानीते 'he recognizes his cow'.
13077: When an upapada indicates fruit accruing to agent, pada is optional: स्वं यजति or यजते 'he sacrifices for himself'.
13078: For all other verbs marking the agent (active voice), parasmaipada is used: याति 'he goes', पचति 'he cooks'.
13079: After कृ preceded by अनु or परा, parasmaipada is used even when fruit accrues to agent: अनुकरोति 'he imitates'.
13080: After क्षिप् preceded by अभि, प्रति, or अति, parasmaipada is used: अभिक्षिपति 'he throws on'.
13081: After वह् preceded by प्र, parasmaipada is used: प्रवहति 'it flows'.
13082: After मृष् preceded by परि, parasmaipada is used: परिमृष्यति 'he endures'.
13083: After रम् preceded by वि, आ, or परि, parasmaipada is used: विरमति 'he rests'.
13084: After रम् preceded by उप, parasmaipada is used: उपरमति 'he causes to refrain'.
13085: After रम् preceded by उप when intransitive, pada is optional: उपरमति or उपरमते.
13086: Causatives of बुध्, युध्, नश्, जन्, इङ्, प्रु, द्रु, and स्रु take parasmaipada: बोधयति 'he awakens'.
13087: Causatives not meaning 'eating' or 'moving' take parasmaipada: भोजयति 'he feeds'.
13088: Causatives of intransitive verbs with sentient agents take parasmaipada: शाययति 'he causes to lie down'.
13089: But causatives of पा, दम्, आयम्, आयस्, परिमुह्, रुच्, नृत्, वद्, and वस् take ātmanepada: पाययते 'he causes to drink'.
13090: Denominatives ending in क्यष् optionally take parasmaipada: लोहितायति or लोहितायते 'he reddens'.
13091: The द्युतादि roots optionally take parasmaipada in the aorist: अद्युतत् or अद्योतिष्ट 'he shone'.
13092: The वृतादि roots (वृत्, वृध्, etc.) optionally take parasmaipada before स्य and सन्: वर्त्स्यति or वर्तिष्यते.
13093: After क्लिप्, parasmaipada is optional in लुट्, स्य, and सन्: कल्प्तासि or कल्प्तासे 'you will be'.
14001: From here to 2.2.38, when a term has multiple designations, only one applies at a time.
14002: When two rules of equal force conflict, the later rule prevails.
14003: Feminine words ending in long ई or ऊ are called nadī.
14004: Words taking इयङ् or उवङ् substitutes are not nadī—except स्त्री, which is always nadī.
14005: Before आम् (genitive plural), इयङ्/उवङ्-taking words are optionally nadī—but स्त्री is always nadī.
14006: Before ङित् affixes, feminines in short इ/उ and इयङ्/उवङ्-words are optionally nadī—except स्त्री.
14007: Other words ending in short इ or उ are called ghi—except सखि.
14008: The word पति is ghi only when in a compound: प्रजापतये but पत्ये.
14009: In the Vedas, पति with a genitive is optionally ghi: कुलुञ्चानां पतये or पत्ये.
14010: A short vowel is called laghu (light).
14011: A short vowel followed by a consonant cluster is called guru (heavy).
14012: A long vowel is also called guru (heavy).
14013: When an affix is prescribed after something, the entire form from that point is called aṅga (base).
14014: A word ending in सुप् (case-affix) or तिङ् (personal ending) is called pada (inflected word).
14015: A word ending in न् is called pada when क्यच्, क्यङ्, or क्यष् follows.
14016: When a सित् affix follows, what precedes is called pada.
14017: When a non-sarvanāmasthāna affix from सु to कप् follows, what precedes is called pada.
14018: When such an affix begins with य् or a vowel, what precedes is called bha (not pada).
14019: A word ending in त् or स् is bha when a मत्वर्थीय affix follows.
14020: Forms like अयस्मय are valid in Vedic usage.
14021: A plural affix is used to denote multiplicity.
14022: Dual and singular affixes are used for two and one respectively.
14023: The term kāraka (case-relation) applies from here onward.
14024: The fixed point from which departure occurs is called apādāna (ablative source).
14025: With verbs of fear or protection, the source of fear is apādāna.
14026: With पराजि 'to find unbearable', what becomes unbearable is apādāna.
14027: With verbs of prevention, the desired object from which one is blocked is apādāna.
14028: In concealment, the person whose sight one avoids is apādāna.
14029: In formal learning, the teacher is apādāna: उपाध्यायादधीते 'he learns from the teacher'.
14030: The source of what is born is apādāna: शृङ्गाच्छरो जायते 'the arrow is born from horn'.
14031: The source of भू is apādāna: हिमवतो गङ्गा प्रभवति 'the Ganges originates from the Himalayas'.
14032: The person one wishes to connect with the object of giving is sampradāna (recipient).
14033: With verbs of liking (रुच्), the one pleased is sampradāna: देवदत्ताय रोचते 'it pleases Devadatta'.
14034: With श्लाघ्, ह्नु, स्था, शप्, the person one informs is sampradāna.
14035: With धारि 'to owe', the creditor is sampradāna: देवदत्ताय शतं धारयति 'he owes 100 to Devadatta'.
14036: With स्पृह् 'to desire', the thing desired is sampradāna: पुष्पेभ्यः स्पृहयति 'he desires flowers'.
14037: With verbs of anger (क्रुध्), malice (द्रुह्), envy (ईर्ष्या), fault-finding (असूया), the target is sampradāna.
14038: But क्रुध् and द्रुह् with upasargas take karma (accusative): देवदत्तमभिक्रुध्यति.
14039: With राध् and ईक्ष्, the person consulted about fortune is sampradāna.
14040: With प्रतिश्रु or आश्रु 'to promise', the promisee is sampradāna.
14041: With अनुगृ or प्रतिगृ 'to encourage', the prior agent being encouraged is sampradāna.
14042: The most effective auxiliary in accomplishing an action is karaṇa (instrument).
14043: With दिव् 'to play', the instrument is optionally karma: अक्षान् दीव्यति or अक्षैर्दीव्यति.
14044: In hiring for wages, the payment is optionally sampradāna: शताय or शतेन परिक्रीतः.
14045: The location where the action occurs (via agent or object) is adhikaraṇa (locative).
14046: With शी, स्था, आस् preceded by अधि, the location is karma: ग्राममधिशेते 'he occupies the village'.
14047: With अभिनिविश्, the location is optionally karma: ग्राममभिनिविशते.
14048: With वस् preceded by उप, अनु, or आ, the location is karma: ग्राममुपवसति.
14049: What the agent most desires to accomplish is karma (object): कटं करोति 'he makes the mat'.
14050: What is not desired but becomes similarly connected with the action is also karma.
14051: An unstated (akathita) kāraka relation is also karma—hence double accusatives with दुह्, याच्, etc.
14052: Causatives of motion, knowledge, eating, literary-object, and intransitive verbs make the primitive agent into karma.
14053: With हृ and कृ causatives, the primitive agent is optionally karma: कारयति कटं देवदत्तं or देवदत्तेन.
14054: The independent, principal source of action chosen by the speaker is kartā (agent).
14055: The mover of an independent agent is called hetu (causer) and is also kartā.
14056: From here to 1.4.97, the terms described are called nipāta (particle).
14057: The words च, वा, etc. are nipātas when not denoting substances.
14058: The words प्र, परा, etc. are nipātas when not denoting substances.
14059: The words प्र, etc. are called upasarga when in composition with a verb: प्रणयति.
14060: The words प्र, etc. are also called gati when with a verb: प्रकृत्य 'having done forth'.
14061: The words ऊरी, etc. and च्वि/डाच्-ending words are gati with कृ, भू, or अस्.
14062: A sound-imitative word not followed by इति is gati: खाट्कृत्य.
14063: सत् and असत् meaning 'respect/disrespect' are gati with a verb: सत्कृत्य 'having honored'.
14064: अलम् meaning 'ornament' is gati: अलंकृत्य 'having adorned'.
14065: अन्तर् meaning 'non-acceptance' is gati: अन्तर्हत्य 'having abandoned'.
14066: कणे and मनस् meaning 'satisfaction' are gati: मनोहत्य 'having satisfied the mind'.
14067: The indeclinable पुरस् is gati: पुरस्कृत्य 'having placed in front'.
14068: The indeclinable अस्तम् is gati: अस्तंगत्य 'having set (of the sun)'.
14069: The indeclinable अच्छ with motion/speech verbs is gati: अच्छगत्य.
14070: The word अदस् not used demonstratively is gati: अदःकृत्य.
14071: तिरस् meaning 'disappearance' is gati: तिरोभूय 'having disappeared'.
14072: तिरस् with कृ is optionally gati: तिरःकृत्य or तिरस्कृत्य.
14073: उपाजे and अन्वाजे 'support' with कृ are optionally gati.
14074: साक्षात् etc. with कृ are optionally gati: साक्षात्कृत्य or साक्षात्कृत्वा.
14075: उरसि and मनसि (not meaning 'placing') with कृ are optionally gati: उरसिकृत्य or उरसिकृत्वा.
14076: मध्ये, पदे, निवचने (not meaning 'placing') with कृ are optionally gati.
14077: हस्ते and पाणौ meaning 'marriage' with कृ are always gati: पाणौकृत्य 'having married'.
14078: The indeclinable प्राध्वम् meaning 'binding' with कृ is always gati.
14079: जीविका and उपनिषद् meaning 'resemblance' with कृ are gati.
14080: Gati and upasarga particles are placed before the verb (as prefixes).
14081: In the Vedas, gati and upasarga may also follow the verb: उपनिष्कृतम् for उपकृतम्.
14082: In the Vedas, gati/upasarga may be separated from the verb: उप प्रयोभिरागतम्.
14083: From here to 1.4.97, terms described are called karmapravachanīya.
14084: अनु denoting a sign is karmapravachanīya: जपमनु प्रावर्षत् 'it rained after prayers'.
14085: अनु with instrumental sense is karmapravachanīya: नदीमनु 'along the river'.
14086: अनु meaning 'inferior to' is karmapravachanīya: अनुशाकटायनं वैयाकरणाः 'grammarians are inferior to Śākaṭāyana'.
14087: उप meaning 'superior/inferior' is karmapravachanīya: उपखार्यां द्रोणः 'a droṇa exceeds a khārī'.
14088: अप and परि meaning 'exclusion' are karmapravachanīya: अपत्रिगर्तेभ्यः 'except Trigarta'.
14089: आङ् expressing limit is karmapravachanīya: आपाटलिपुत्रात् 'up to (excluding) Pāṭaliputra'.
14090: प्रति, परि, अनु with senses of sign, circumstance, division, or pervasion are karmapravachanīya.
14091: अभि is karmapravachanīya in those senses—except 'division'.
14093: अधि and परि as expletives are karmapravachanīya.
14094: सु meaning 'respect' is karmapravachanīya: सुस्तुतं भवता 'well-praised by you'.
14095: अति meaning 'excess' or 'respect' is karmapravachanīya: अतिसिक्तम् 'abundantly sprinkled'.
14096: अपि with senses of 'somewhat', 'possibility', 'permission', 'censure', or 'collection' is karmapravachanīya.
14097: अधि meaning 'lordship' is karmapravachanīya: अधि ब्रह्मदत्ते पञ्चालाः 'Brahmadatta rules the Pañcālas'.
14098: अधि with कृ is optionally karmapravachanīya.
14099: Substitutes for ल are called parasmaipada: तिप्, तस्, झि, सिप्, थस्, थ, मिप्, वस्, मस्.
14100: The nine तङ् affixes and आन-ending affixes (शानच्, कानच्) are called ātmanepada.
14101: The three triads of तिङ् are called prathama (3rd), madhyama (2nd), and uttama (1st) person.
14102: Within each triad, the three are called ekavacana (sg.), dvivacana (du.), and bahuvacana (pl.).
14103: The case-affixes (सुप्) also have singular, dual, and plural in each set of three.
14104: Triads of personal and case endings are called vibhakti (inflection).
14105: When युष्मद् (you) is the referent, madhyama (2nd person) is used: त्वं पचसि 'you cook'.
14106: In joking contexts, 2nd person is used with मन्ये, which itself takes 1st person singular.
14107: When अस्मद् (I) is the referent, uttama (1st person) is used: अहं पचामि 'I cook'.
14108: In other cases (neither 'you' nor 'I'), prathama (3rd person) is used: पचति 'he cooks'.
14109: The closest proximity of sounds (half a mātrā apart) is called saṃhitā (connected speech).
14110: The absence of a following sound is called avasāna (pause).
21001: Rules about complete words (pada) apply only when those words are connected in meaning (samartha). This governs compounding, case assignment, and treating one word as part of another.
21002: A word with a case-ending before a vocative is treated as part of that vocative for accent purposes. So शुभस्पती accents like पती 'O lords of prosperity'.
21003: From here through 2.2.38, what we describe is called samāsa (compound). The term samāsa must be supplied in each relevant sūtra.
21004: The words 'with a case-ending' (सुप् सुपा) govern subsequent sūtras—either both words, or various combinations as context requires.
21005: From here onward, compounds described are called avyayībhāva (adverbial compound), where the first member's sense is principal.
21006: An indeclinable is invariably compounded with a case-ending word when denoting: case-force, nearness, prosperity, adversity, absence, departure, 'no longer', sound-production, 'after', 'according to', sequence, simultaneity, resemblance, fitness, totality, or limit.
21007: The indeclinable यथा (except when meaning 'likeness') invariably compounds: यथावृद्धम् 'according to seniority'. No compound in यथा देवदत्तः 'like Devadatta'.
21008: The indeclinable यावत् meaning 'limitation' invariably compounds: यावदमत्रम् 'as many as pots'. No compound when meaning duration: यावद्दत्तम्.
21009: A case-ending word compounds with प्रति meaning 'a little': शाकप्रति 'a little vegetable'. प्रति stands last since it's in the instrumental.
21010: अक्ष, शलाका, or numerals compound with परि for unlucky gambling throws: अक्षपरि 'bad throw of dice'.
21011: From here on, compounds are optional (विभाषा). The same meaning can be expressed without compounding.
21012: अप, परि, बहिस्, and अञ्चु-ending direction words optionally compound with an ablative: अपत्रिगर्तम् or अपत्रिगर्तेभ्यः 'away from Trigarta'.
21013: आङ् meaning 'limit' (inclusive or exclusive) optionally compounds with an ablative: आपाटलिपुत्रम् or आपाटलिपुत्रात् 'up to Pāṭaliputra'.
21014: अभि and प्रति meaning 'direction toward a goal' optionally compound with accusative: अभ्यग्नि or अग्निमभि 'toward the fire'.
21015: अनु meaning 'nearness' optionally compounds: अनुवनम् 'near the forest'. Not when meaning 'toward': वृक्षमनु.
21016: अनु expressing 'measured length' optionally compounds: अनुगङ्गम् 'alongside the Ganges' (measuring Varanasi's length by the river).
21017: Words like तिष्ठद्गु (time epithets) are invariably avyayībhāva compounds: तिष्ठद्गु 'cow-milking time'.
21018: पार 'across' and मध्य 'middle', becoming परे and मध्ये, optionally compound with genitives: पारेगङ्गम् or गङ्गापारम् 'across the Ganges'.
21019: A numeral may compound with a word meaning 'family member': द्विमुनि व्याकरणस्य 'grammar with two sages (Pāṇini and Patañjali)'.
21020: A numeral compounds with river names for aggregates: सप्तगङ्गम् 'where seven Ganges streams meet'.
21021: A case-ending word invariably compounds with river names when the compound is an appellative denoting something other than its parts: उन्मत्तगङ्गम् 'the Unmatta-gaṅga region'.
21022: From here through 2.2.23, the word tatpuruṣa is understood. In tatpuruṣa, the last member's sense is principal.
21023: Dvigu compounds are also tatpuruṣa—so samāsānta rules apply: पञ्चराज्ञी 'five kings (aggregate)', दशगवम् 'ten cows'.
21024: A word with 2nd case-affix compounds with श्रित, अतीत, पतित, गत, अत्यस्त, प्राप्त, or आपन्न: कष्टश्रितः 'having resorted to hardship'.
21025: The indeclinable स्वयम् compounds with a क्त-ending word: स्वयंकृतम् 'self-made'. This makes them one word for accent.
21026: खट्वा in the accusative compounds with क्त when censure is implied: खट्वारूढः 'lazy fool' (lit. 'bedstead-ascender').
21027: The indeclinable सामि 'half' compounds with क्त-ending words: सामिकृतम् 'half-done', सामिपीतम् 'half-drunk'.
21028: Time-words in the accusative optionally compound with क्त (not for duration): मासप्रभृतः 'beginning from the month'.
21029: Time-words in the accusative optionally compound with case-ending words when meaning complete duration: मुहूर्तसुखम् 'momentary pleasure'.
21030: A word with 3rd case-affix optionally compounds with quality-words (when that quality is caused by the instrumental) or अर्थ: शङ्कुलाखण्डः 'cut by nippers', धान्यार्थः 'wealth from grain'.
21031: A 3rd-case word compounds with पूर्व, सदृश, सम, 'less-words', कलह, निपुण, मिश्र, श्लक्ष्ण: मासपूर्वः 'prior by a month', मातृसदृशः 'like mother'.
21032: An instrumental denoting agent/instrument diversely compounds with kṛt-words: अहिहतः 'snake-killed', नखनिर्भिन्नः 'nail-pierced'. 'Diversely' allows exceptions.
21033: An instrumental (agent/instrument) optionally compounds with kṛtya-words when hyperbole is intended: काकपेया नदी 'crow-drinkable river' (so shallow a crow can drink from it).
21034: An instrumental denoting condiment optionally compounds with food-words: दध्योदनः 'curd-rice' (rice prepared with curd).
21035: An instrumental denoting flavoring compounds with victual-words: गुडधानाः 'jaggery-barley' (barley mixed with jaggery).
21036: A word with 4th case-affix compounds with words meaning 'for that purpose', or with अर्थ, बलि, हित, सुख, रक्षित: यूपदारु 'wood for sacrificial post', गोहितम् 'good for cows'.
21037: A 5th-case word optionally compounds with भय: वृकभयम् 'fear of wolves'. Also with भीत, भीति, भी.
21038: A 5th-case word compounds with अपेत, अपोढ, मुक्त, पतित, अपत्रस्त when gradual separation: सुखापेतः 'departed from happiness'. Not for sudden falls.
21039: Words meaning 'little', 'near', 'far', 'difficulty' in the ablative compound with क्त: स्तोकान्मुक्तः 'freed from a little distance'. The case-affix is retained.
21040: A 7th-case word compounds with शौण्ड-class words: अक्षशौण्डः 'skilled in dice', अक्षधूर्तः 'cunning in dice'.
21041: A 7th-case word compounds with सिद्ध, शुष्क, पक्व, बन्ध: आतपशुष्कः 'sun-dried', स्थालीपक्वः 'pot-cooked', चक्रबन्धः 'wheel-bound'.
21042: A 7th-case word compounds with ध्वाङ्क्ष 'crow' (and synonyms) when contempt is implied: तीर्थध्वाङ्क्षः 'pilgrimage-crow' (greedy person).
21043: A 7th-case word compounds with kṛtya-words (यत्/ण्यत्): मासदेयम् 'payable within a month', प्रातरध्येयः 'to be studied in morning'.
21044: A 7th-case word invariably compounds with a case-ending word when the result is an appellative: अरण्येतिलकाः 'wild sesamum' (worthless thing).
21045: Time-division words (पूर्वाह्ण, etc.) in the locative compound with क्त-words: पूर्वाह्णकृतम् 'done in the forenoon'.
21046: The indeclinable तत्र compounds with क्त-words: तत्रभुक्तम् 'eaten there'. Forms one word for accent.
21047: A 7th-case word compounds with क्त when censure is implied: उदके विशीर्णम् 'dried in water' (something impossible).
21048: Words like पात्रेसम्मित 'dish-companion' (parasite) are tatpuruṣa compounds implying censure. Their first member takes initial udātta.
21049: Words denoting prior action, and एक, सर्व, जरत्, पुराण, नव, केवल, compound with same-case words: स्नातानुलिप्तः 'bathed-and-anointed', एकशाटी 'one-petticoat'.
21050: Direction-words or numerals compound with same-case words when the result is an appellative: पूर्वेषुकामशमी 'Iṣukāmaśamī-in-the-east', सप्तर्षयः 'the Seven Sages'.
21051: Direction-words or numerals compound when: taddhita-sense applies, another member follows, or aggregate is expressed: पौर्वशालः 'of the eastern hall', पञ्चगवधनः 'whose wealth is five cows'.
21052: A compound with a numeral as first member, in those same contexts, is called dvigu: पञ्चकपालः 'five-cup offering', पञ्चपूली 'five bundles'.
21053: Words expressing vileness compound with words of contempt (contemptible word second): वैयाकरणखसूचि 'ignorant grammarian'. Vileness qualifies the person, not inherently.
21054: पाप and अणक 'contemptible' come first when compounded with contempt-words: पापनापितः 'contemptible barber'. This overrides the previous rule.
21055: The object of comparison compounds with what shares common quality: घनश्यामः 'cloud-dark' (dark like a cloud). Not when no common quality.
21056: The compared object compounds with व्याघ्र-class words (standard of comparison) without stating the common quality: पुरुषव्याघ्रः 'man-tiger' (brave man).
21057: An adjective diversely compounds with its substantive: नीलोत्पलम् 'blue lotus'. 'Diversely' means sometimes obligatory, sometimes optional, sometimes blocked.
21058: पूर्व, अपर, प्रथम, चरम, जघन्य, समान, मध्य, मध्यम, वीर compound with same-case words: पूर्वपुरुषः 'ancestor', वीरपुरुषः 'heroic person'.
21059: श्रेणि-class words compound with कृत-class words (implying च्वि force): श्रेणिकृताः 'made into classes' (what wasn't classed before).
21060: A क्त-word without नञ् compounds with the same क्त-word with नञ्: कृताकृतम् 'done and not done', भुक्ताभुक्तम् 'eaten and uneaten'.
21061: सत्, महत्, परम, उत्तम, उत्कृष्ट compound with words denoting persons worthy of respect: सत्पुरुषः 'good person', महापुरुषः 'great person'.
21062: A word denoting something worthy of respect compounds with वृन्दारक, नाग, कुञ्जर: गोवृन्दारकः 'excellent cow', गोनागः 'excellent bull'.
21063: कतर 'which of two' and कतम 'which of many' compound when asking about genus: कतरकठः 'which one is Kaṭha?'. Not when asking about individuals.
21064: किम् compounds when implying censure: किंराजा 'what kind of king!' (a bad one). Not when merely questioning possession.
21065: A genus-word compounds with पोटा, युवति, स्तोक, कतिपय, गृष्टि, धेनु, वशा, वेहत्, बष्कयणी, प्रवक्तृ, श्रोत्रिय, अध्यापक, धूर्त: गोगृष्टिः 'cow that has calved once'.
21066: A genus-word compounds with words of praise: गोप्रकाण्डम् 'an excellent cow'. These praise-words retain their gender.
21067: युवन् 'young' compounds with खलति, पलित, वलिन, जरत्: युवखलतिः 'bald in youth'. The feminine जरती shows gender-variants apply.
21068: Kṛt-ending words and तुल्य (and synonyms) compound with non-genus words in the same case: भोज्योष्णम् 'hot food', तुल्यश्वेतः 'equally white'.
21069: A color-word compounds with another color-word in the same case: कृष्णसारङ्गः 'spotted with black', लोहितसारङ्गः 'spotted with red'.
21070: कुमार 'young' compounds with श्रमण-class words: कुमारश्रमणः 'young ascetic'. कुमार takes the gender of the following word.
21071: A quadruped-genus-word compounds with गर्भिणी: गोगर्भिणी 'pregnant cow'. Not for individuals or humans.
21072: मयूरव्यंसक-class words are irregular tatpuruṣa compounds: मयूरव्यंसक 'peacock-cunning'. The च restricts: no परममयूरव्यंसक.
22001: पूर्व, अपर, अधर, उत्तर compound with words denoting a thing having parts, when that thing is numerically one: पूर्वकायः 'front of the body'. This overrides genitive tatpuruṣa.
22002: अर्ध 'half' (neuter, meaning exact bisection) compounds with words denoting a thing with parts (numerically one): अर्धपिप्पली 'half a pepper'. Masculine अर्ध follows rule 2.2.8.
22003: द्वितीय, तृतीय, चतुर्थ, तुर्य optionally compound with words denoting things with parts (numerically one): द्वितीयभिक्षा or भिक्षाद्वितीयम् 'second begging'.
22004: प्राप्त and आपन्न optionally compound with accusative words—an alternative to 2.1.24: प्राप्तजीविकः or जीविकाप्राप्तः 'obtained livelihood'.
22005: Time-words compound with words denoting what is measured by that time: मासजातः 'month-old' (born a month ago).
22006: The negative नञ् compounds with a case-ending word: अब्राह्मणः 'non-Brahmin'. नञ् has six senses: resemblance, absence, difference, smallness, unfitness, contrariety.
22007: ईषत् 'slightly' compounds with non-kṛt quality-words: ईषत्पिङ्गलः 'slightly brown'. Not with substantives: no *ईषद्गार्ग्यः.
22008: A word with 6th case-affix compounds with a case-ending word: राजपुरुषः 'king's man'. Also with kṛt-words when genitive is from kṛt-relation.
22009: A 6th-case word compounds with याजक-class words despite rule 2.2.16: ब्राह्मणयाजकः 'one who sacrifices for Brahmins'.
22010: A genitive is not compounded when it means specification (निर्धारण): क्षत्रियो मनुष्याणां शूरतमः 'the Kṣatriya is bravest among men'.
22011: A genitive is not compounded with: ordinals, adjectives, words of satisfaction, सत्-participles, indeclinables, तव्य-words, or same-referent words.
22012: A genitive is not compounded with क्त when क्त means 'respect/understanding/inclination': राज्ञां पूजितः 'respected by the king'.
22013: A genitive is not compounded with क्त when क्त denotes location (from roots of fixedness, motion, eating): इदमेषामासितम् 'this is where they sat'.
22014: A genitive is not compounded when it has accusative force (object of a kṛt-noun with both agent and object expressed): गवां दोहोऽगोपालकेन 'milking of cows by a non-cowherd'.
22015: A genitive (when denoting agent) is not compounded with words ending in तृच् or अक denoting agency: भवतः शायिका 'your lying down'.
22016: A genitive is not compounded with तृच् or अक when they denote agent: अपां स्रष्टा 'creator of waters'. पां भोजकः 'eater of rice'.
22017: A genitive is invariably compounded with अक when it means sport or livelihood: उद्दालकपुष्पभञ्जिका 'flower-breaking game', दन्तलेखकः 'tooth-painter (profession)'.
22018: कु 'bad', gati-words, and प्र etc. invariably compound: कुपुरुषः 'bad man', दुष्पुरुषः 'wicked man', उररीकृतम् 'acknowledged'.
22019: An upapada not ending in a tense-affix invariably compounds with its kṛt-word: कुम्भकारः 'pot-maker'. Compounding occurs before case-affixes are added.
22020: An upapada compounds with indeclinables only when they end in अम् (ण्मुल्-affix): स्वादुकारं भुङ्क्ते 'he eats having made it sweet'. Not with तुमुन्-forms.
22021: An upapada with 3rd case-affix (etc.) optionally compounds with अम्-ending indeclinables: मूलकोपदंशं or मूलकेनोपदंशम् 'having relished with radish'.
22022: An upapada with 3rd case (etc.) optionally compounds with क्त्वा-words: उच्चैःकृत्य or उच्चैःकृत्वा. When compounded, ल्यप् replaces क्त्वा.
22023: The remaining compound is called bahuvrīhi. Its meaning goes beyond the individual members.
22024: Two or more case-ending words form a bahuvrīhi when the compound denotes something new: प्राप्तोदको ग्रामः 'village that has received water', चित्रगुः 'one having a spotted cow'.
22025: Indeclinables, आसन्न, अदूर, अधिक, and numerals compound with numerals when the sense is a numeral: उपदशाः 'about ten', द्वित्राः 'two or three'.
22026: Direction-words compound when signifying an intermediate point: दक्षिणपूर्वा 'south-east'. Not with derivative direction-words like ऐन्द्री.
22027: Homonymous words (both locative or both instrumental) compound for 'fighting': केशाकेशि 'hair-to-hair fight', दण्डादण्डि 'stick-fight'. Final इ is added.
22028: सह compounds with an instrumental when the companion and accompanied share equally in the action: सपुत्रः 'accompanied by son'. The स replaces सह.
22029: Words in a relation expressible by 'and' form a dvandva compound. This applies when the sense is mutual conjunction or aggregate.
22030: The upasarjana (subordinate member) is placed first in compounds: राजपुरुषः not *पुरुषराजः.
22031: In राजदन्त-class words, the upasarjana is placed last: राजदन्तः 'chief of teeth' (eyetooth), not *दन्तराजः.
22032: In dvandva, a ghi-word (short इ/उ ending) is placed first: हरिहरौ 'Hari and Hara', पटुगुप्तौ.
22033: In dvandva, a word beginning with a vowel and ending in short अ is placed first: उष्ट्रखरम् 'camel and donkey'.
22034: In dvandva, the word with fewer vowels is placed first: प्लक्षन्यग्रोधौ (2 vs 3 vowels).
22035: In bahuvrīhi, a locative-case word and an adjective are placed first: कण्ठेकालः 'black-throated', चित्रगुः 'spotted-cow-having'.
22036: In bahuvrīhi, a niṣṭhā (क्त/क्तवतु) word is placed first: कृतकठः 'one who has made a mat'.
22037: In आहिताग्नि-class words, the niṣṭhā-word may optionally be placed first: आहिताग्निः or अग्न्याहितः 'one who has consecrated fire'.
22038: In karmadhāraya, कडार-class words may optionally be placed first: कडारजैमिनिः or जैमिनिकडारः 'tawny Jaimini'. This ends the scope of 1.4.1 and 2.1.3.
23001: The word अनभिहित 'unexpressed' governs subsequent rules. Case-affixes apply only when the kāraka relation is not already expressed by verb-endings, kṛt, taddhita, or compounds.
23002: When the object (karma) is not marked by the verb ending, it takes the 2nd case (accusative): कटं करोति 'he makes a mat'. उभयतः, सर्वतः, धिक्, etc. also govern accusative.
23003: In the Vedas, the object of हु 'to sacrifice' optionally takes instrumental or accusative: यवाग्वाग्निहोत्रं जुहोति or यवागुमग्निहोत्रं जुहोति.
23004: A word governed by अन्तरा or अन्तरेण takes accusative: अन्तरेण त्वां च मां च 'between you and me'. This overrides genitive.
23005: A time-word or distance-word takes accusative when denoting complete, uninterrupted duration: मासमधीते 'he studies for a full month', क्रोशं पर्वतः 'the mountain extends a full kos'.
23006: A time-word or distance-word takes instrumental when denoting accomplishment within that span: मासेनानुवाकोऽधीतः 'he learned the section in a month'.
23007: A time-word or distance-word takes locative or ablative when denoting interval between actions: द्व्यहे or द्व्यहात् 'in/after two days', क्रोशे or क्रोशात् 'at a distance of one kos'.
23008: A word governed by a karmapravachanīya takes accusative: शाकल्यस्य संहितामनुप्रावर्षत् 'it rained following Śākalya's recitation'.
23009: When the karmapravachanīya means 'more than' (उप) or 'lord of' (अधि), the word takes locative: उपखार्यां द्रोणः 'a droṇa exceeds a khārī', अधिब्रह्मदत्ते पञ्चालाः.
23010: With the karmapravachanīyas अप, आङ्, परि, the word takes ablative: अपपाटलिपुत्रादावृष्टो देवः 'it rained except for Pāṭaliputra'.
23011: With प्रति meaning 'substitute' or 'exchange', the word takes ablative: तिलेभ्यः प्रतियच्छति माषान् 'he exchanges māṣas for sesame'.
23012: With verbs of motion, the destination takes accusative or dative—unless it's a road-word and physical motion is meant: ग्रामं/ग्रामाय गच्छति 'he goes to the village'.
23013: The recipient (sampradāna) takes dative: उपाध्यायाय गां ददाति 'he gives a cow to the teacher'. Also for 'purpose': यूपाय दारु 'wood for the post'.
23014: When an infinitive of purpose is unexpressed, its object takes dative: फलेभ्यो व्रजति = फलान्याहर्तुं व्रजति 'he goes for fruits'.
23015: A bhāva-suffix word with infinitive meaning takes dative: यागाय व्रजति = यष्टुं व्रजति 'he goes to sacrifice'.
23016: With नमस्, स्वस्ति, स्वाहा, स्वधा, अलम्, वषट्, the word takes dative: नमो देवेभ्यः 'salutation to gods', अलं मल्लो मल्लाय 'a wrestler is a match for a wrestler'.
23017: The object of मन्य 'consider' optionally takes dative when contempt is shown (and the object is inanimate): न त्वा तृणं/तृणाय मन्ये 'I don't consider you worth a straw'.
23018: The agent (kartṛ) or instrument (karaṇa) takes instrumental: देवदत्तेन कृतम् 'done by Devadatta', दात्रेण लुनाति 'he cuts with a sickle'.
23019: With सह 'together with', the accompaniment takes instrumental—when it's not the principal: पुत्रेण सहागतः पिता 'father came with son'.
23020: The defective limb by which a person's defect is described takes instrumental: अक्ष्णा काणः 'blind in one eye', पादेन खञ्जः 'lame in foot'.
23021: The sign/mark by which a state is indicated takes instrumental: जटाभिस्तापसः 'he is an ascetic by his matted hair'.
23022: With सम्-ज्ञा, the object optionally takes instrumental: पित्रा/पितरं संजानीते 'he recognizes his father'.
23023: The cause (hetu) takes instrumental: विद्यया यशः 'fame through learning', धनेन कुलम् 'family through wealth'.
23024: A debt considered as cause (but not agent) takes ablative: शताद्बद्धः 'imprisoned for a debt of one hundred'.
23025: A quality-word (abstract noun, not feminine) as cause optionally takes ablative: जाड्याद्/जाड्येन बद्धः 'imprisoned due to stupidity'.
23026: When हेतु is used, the cause takes genitive: अन्नस्य हेतोर्वसति 'he dwells for the sake of food'.
23027: With a pronoun plus हेतु, both genitive and instrumental are possible: कस्य/केन हेतुना 'for what reason'. With निमित्त/कारण, all cases work.
23028: The apādāna (source of separation) takes ablative: ग्रामादागच्छति 'he comes from the village', वृकाद्बिभेति 'he fears the wolf'.
23029: With words meaning 'other', आरात् 'near/far', इतर, ऋते 'without', direction-words, अञ्चु-compounds, आच्/आहि-words, ablative is used: अन्यो देवदत्तात् 'other than Devadatta'.
23030: With words ending in अतसुच् affixes (दक्षिणतः etc.), genitive is used: ग्रामस्य दक्षिणतः 'south of the village'.
23031: With words ending in एनप्, both accusative and genitive are used: दक्षिणेन ग्रामं/ग्रामस्य 'south of the village'.
23032: With पृथक्, विना, नाना, instrumental is optionally used (along with ablative and accusative): रामेण/रामाद्/रामं विना 'without Rāma'.
23033: स्तोक, अल्प, कृच्छ्र, कतिपय meaning instrument (not substance) optionally take ablative: स्तोकात्/स्तोकेन मुक्तः 'released with little (effort)'.
23034: With words meaning 'far' or 'near', genitive is optionally used: ग्रामात्/ग्रामस्य दूरम् 'far from the village'.
23035: After दूर and अन्तिक, accusative, ablative, or instrumental is used: दूरं/दूरात्/दूरेण ग्रामस्य.
23036: The location (adhikaraṇa) takes locative: कटे आस्ते 'he sits on the mat'. Also with दूर/अन्तिक: अन्तिके ग्रामस्य 'near the village'.
23037: The action whose occurrence marks the time of another action takes locative (locative absolute): गोषु दुह्यमानासु गतः 'he went while the cows were being milked'.
23038: When disregard is shown, genitive absolute is used: रुदतः/रुदति प्राव्राजीत् 'he left despite her weeping'.
23039: With स्वामिन्, ईश्वर, अधिपति, दायाद, साक्षिन्, प्रतिभू, प्रसूत, both genitive and locative work: गवां/गोषु स्वामी 'master of cows'.
23040: With आयुक्त or कुशल meaning 'deeply absorbed', both genitive and locative work: कटकरणे/कटकरणस्य आयुक्तः 'absorbed in mat-making'.
23041: In specification (निर्धारण), both genitive and locative work: गवां/गोषु कृष्णा बहुक्षीरा 'among cows, the black one gives most milk'.
23042: When the specified differs from the group, ablative is used: माथुराः पाटलिपुत्रेभ्यः सुकुमारतराः 'Mathura people are more delicate than those of Pāṭaliputra'.
23043: With साधु/निपुण meaning 'good toward', locative is used (unless प्रति is present): मातरि साधुः 'good toward mother'. Not in साधुर्देवदत्तो मातरं प्रति.
23044: With प्रसित and उत्सुक, both instrumental and locative work: निद्रायां/निद्रया उत्सुकः 'longing for sleep'.
23045: When a nakṣatra-taddhita is लुप्-elided, both locative and instrumental work: पुष्येण/पुष्ये 'when the moon is in Puṣya'.
23046: The 1st case (nominative) is used for: stem-meaning, gender, measure, or number: वृक्षः 'tree', द्रोणः 'a droṇa measure', एकः 'one'.
23047: The nominative is also used for addressing (vocative sense): हे राम 'O Rāma'.
23048: A nominative word in the sense of address is called āmantrita (vocative).
23049: The vocative singular is called sambuddhi: हे राम (the म् is elided).
23050: In remaining cases (relations like ownership), genitive is used: राज्ञः पुरुषः 'king's man', पशोः पादः 'animal's foot'.
23051: With ज्ञा (not meaning 'to know'), the instrument takes genitive: मधुनो जानीते 'he engages (in sacrifice) with honey'.
23052: With verbs of remembering, with दय् 'give/pity', and with ईश् 'rule', the object takes genitive: मातुरध्येति 'he remembers mother', गात्राणामीष्टे 'he rules his limbs'.
23053: With कृ meaning 'to transform/prepare', the object takes genitive: एधोदकस्योपस्कुरुते 'he prepares wood and water'.
23054: With रुज्-class verbs (except causative ज्वरय्), when the subject is an abstract noun, the object takes genitive: चौरस्य रुजति रोगः 'disease afflicts the thief'.
23055: With नाथ् meaning 'to bless', the object takes genitive: मधुनो नाथते 'he blesses the honey'.
23056: With उज्जासय्, निहन्, प्रहन्, उन्नाटय्, क्राथय्, पिनष्टि (meaning 'injure'), the object takes genitive: चौरस्योज्जासयति 'he injures the thief'.
23057: With व्यवहृ and पण् meaning 'deal/stake', the object takes genitive: शतस्य व्यवहरति 'he deals in a hundred'.
23058: With दिव् meaning 'stake/deal', the object takes genitive: शतस्य दीव्यति 'he stakes a hundred'.
23059: With दिव् preceded by an upasarga, the object optionally takes genitive: शतस्य/शतं प्रतिदीव्यति 'he stakes a hundred'.
23060: In Brāhmaṇa literature, the object of simple दिव् takes accusative: गामस्य दीव्येयुः 'they would stake a cow'.
23061: With प्रेष्य/ब्रूहि (imperative 'send/tell') denoting oblation to a deity, the object takes genitive: अग्नये छागस्य प्रेष्य 'send the goat for Agni'.
23062: In the Vedas, genitive is diversely used with dative sense: पुरुषमृगश्चन्द्रमसः 'a male deer to the moon'.
23063: In the Vedas, genitive is diversely used for the instrument of यज्: घृतस्य/घृतेन यजते 'he sacrifices with ghee'.
23064: With कृत्वसुच् words ('so many times'), the time-word takes genitive: पञ्चकृत्वोऽह्नः 'five times a day'.
23065: With kṛt-words, the agent and object take genitive: कालिदासस्य क्रिया 'composition of Kālidāsa', पुरां भेत्ता 'destroyer of cities'.
23066: When both agent and object of a kṛt-word are expressed, only the object takes genitive; the agent takes instrumental: गवां दोहोऽगोपालकेन 'milking of cows by a non-cowherd'.
23067: क्त with present-tense meaning (respect, understanding, inclination) takes genitive: राज्ञां पूजितः 'honored by kings'.
23068: क्त denoting location (from roots of fixedness, motion, eating) takes genitive: इदमेषामासितम् 'this is their seat'.
23069: Genitive is not used with: ल/उ/उक-participles, indeclinables, niṣṭhā, खलर्थ-words, or तृन्-words: ओदनं पचन् 'cooking rice' (not *ओदनस्य).
23070: Genitive is not used with अक denoting futurity or इन् denoting futurity/debt: कटं कारको व्रजति 'he goes to make a mat', ग्रामगामी 'one who must go to the village'.
23071: With kṛtya-words, the agent optionally takes genitive; the object always does: भवतः/भवता कटः कर्तव्यः 'the mat is to be made by you'.
23072: With तुल्य-class words (meaning 'like'), both instrumental and genitive work—except with तुला/उपमा which require genitive: तुल्यो देवदत्तेन/देवदत्तस्य 'like Devadatta'.
23073: With आयुष्, मद्र, भद्र, कुशल, सुख, अर्थ, हित (blessing context), both dative and genitive work: आयुष्यं देवदत्ताय/देवदत्तस्य भूयात् 'may there be long life for Devadatta'.
24001: A dvigu (numeral compound) expresses singular sense—the aggregate is treated as one unit: पञ्चगवम् 'a group of five cows', पञ्चपूली. Even when modified by other affixes, singular remains: पञ्चपूलीयं शोभना.
24002: A samāhāra-dvandva (aggregate dvandva) of body parts, musicians, or soldiers takes singular neuter: पाणिपादम् 'hands and feet', शिरोग्रीवम् 'head and neck', मार्दङ्गिकपाणविकम् 'drum players'. This doesn't apply to itaretara-dvandva.
24003: A dvandva of Vedic school names takes singular when repetition (anuvāda) is meant with aorist of स्था/इण्: उदगात् कठकालापम् 'Kaṭha and Kalāpa arose (demonstrating again)'.
24004: A dvandva of Yajurveda sacrifices takes singular if not neuter-gender words: अर्काश्वमेधम् 'the Arka and Aśvamedha sacrifices'. Exception: राजसूयवाजपेयौ (both neuter).
24005: A dvandva of subjects studied in sequence takes singular: पदककक्रमकम् 'one who studied pada and krama arrangements'. Not remote subjects: याज्ञिकवैयाकरणौ (dual).
24006: A dvandva of genus-names (not living beings) takes singular: आराशस्त्रि 'probe and knife', धानाशष्कुलि 'fried rice and barley cake'. Not quality/action names: गमनाकुञ्चनप्रसारणानि (plural).
24007: A dvandva of different-gender river/country names (not towns) takes singular: गंगाशोणम् 'Gaṅgā and Śoṇa'. Same gender: गंगायमुने (dual). Cities: मथुरापाटलिपुत्रम् (singular allowed).
24008: A dvandva of small animals (kṣudrajantu) takes singular: यूकालिक्षम् 'louse and nit', दंशमशकम् 'gnat and mosquito'.
24009: A dvandva of animals with natural enmity takes singular invariably: मार्जारमूषकम् 'cat and rat', अहिनकुलम् 'snake and mongoose', काकोलूकम् 'crow and owl'. No optional plural here.
24010: A dvandva of non-expelled śūdra castes takes singular: तक्षायस्करम् 'carpenter and blacksmith', रजकतन्तुवायम् 'washerman and weaver'. Expelled castes: चण्डालमृतपाः (dual).
24011: The गवाश्व-class compounds take singular: गवाश्वम् 'cow and horse', गवाविकम्, अजाविकम्, मूत्रपुरीषम्, दासीदासम्. Variant forms allow option: गोश्वम् or गोश्वौ.
24012: Dvandvas of trees, wild animals, grass, grain, condiments, domestic beasts/birds, and अश्ववडव/पूर्वपर/अधरोत्तर optionally take singular: प्लक्षन्यग्रोधम्/प्लक्षन्यग्रोधाः, व्रीहियवम्/व्रीहियवाः.
24013: A dvandva of contrary qualities (not substances) optionally takes singular: शीतोष्णम्/शीतोष्णे 'cold and heat', सुखदुःखम्/सुखदुःखे. Substances: शीतोष्णे उदके (dual only).
24014: The दधिपयस्-class compounds don't take singular: दधिपयसी 'curd and milk', सर्पिर्मधुनी, ब्रह्मप्रजापती, उलूखलमुसले, ऋक्सामे.
24015: A dvandva with a fixed number of concrete things doesn't take singular: दश दन्तोष्ठाः 'ten sets of teeth and lips'.
24016: A dvandva with approximate number optionally takes singular: उपदशं दन्तोष्ठम्/उपदशा दन्तोष्ठाः 'nearly ten sets of teeth and lips'.
24017: Dvigu and dvandva compounds that take singular are neuter: दशगवम्, पाणिपादम्, शिरोग्रीवम्. Vartt: Short-अ dvigu is feminine: पञ्चपूली; आप्-ending optionally: पञ्चखट्वम्/पञ्चखट्वी.
24018: An avyayībhāva compound is neuter: अधिस्त्रि 'about a woman', उपकुमारि. Also: पुण्याहम् 'auspicious day', त्रिपथम् 'crossroads', and adverbs: मृदु पचति 'cooks gently'.
24019: A tatpuruṣa (except नञ् or karmadhāraya) becomes neuter in cases specified below: ब्राह्मणसेनम् (optional). But: असेना (नञ्), परमसेना (karmadhāraya) keep original gender.
24020: A tatpuruṣa ending in कन्था ('town'), denoting Uśīnara-region towns, is neuter: सोशमिकन्थम्, आह्वरकन्थम्. Non-appellative or other regions: वीरणकन्था, दाक्षिकन्था.
24021: A tatpuruṣa with उपज्ञा/उपक्रम (invention/commencement) is neuter when meaning origin of a work: पाणिन्युपज्ञम् 'originated by Pāṇini'. Otherwise: देवदत्तोपज्ञो रथः (masculine).
24022: A tatpuruṣa ending in छाया is neuter when meaning profusion: शलभछायम् 'locust-darkened', इक्षुछायम् 'sugarcane groves'. Otherwise: कुड्यच्छाया 'wall's shadow' (feminine).
24023: A tatpuruṣa with सभा preceded by राजन्-synonym or non-human is neuter: इन्द्रसभम् 'Indra's court', रक्षःसभम्. But राजसभा (not synonym), देवदत्तसभा keep feminine.
24024: A tatpuruṣa with सभा meaning concourse (not building) is neuter: स्त्रीसभम्, दासीसभम् 'gathering of women/slaves'. Building: अनाथसभा 'poorhouse' (feminine).
24025: A tatpuruṣa ending in सेना, सुरा, छाया, शाला, निशा is optionally neuter: ब्राह्मणसेना/ब्राह्मणसेनम्, गोशाला/गोशालम्. Except नञ् and karmadhāraya.
24026: A dvandva or tatpuruṣa takes the gender of its final member: कुक्कटमयूर्यौ इमे (feminine from मयूरी), मयूरीकुक्कुटौ इमौ (masculine from कुक्कुट).
24027: अश्ववडव compounds take gender of the first member: अश्ववडवौ इमौ (masculine from अश्व). Exception to the general final-member rule.
24028: In Vedas, हेमन्तशिशिरौ and अहोरात्रे take gender of the first: हेमन्तशिशिरावृतूनाम्, अहोरात्राणीष्टकाः. Classical: हेमन्तशिशिरे (neuter dual).
24029: Dvandva and tatpuruṣa compounds ending in रात्र or अह्न are masculine: द्विरात्रः 'two nights', पूर्वाह्णः 'forenoon', त्र्यहः 'three days'. Also: अनुवाकः, शंयुवाकः.
24030: The compound अपथम् 'wrong path' is neuter: अपथमिदम्, अपथानि गाहते मूढः. But bahuvrīhi: अपथो देशः (masculine).
24031: The अर्धर्च-class words are masculine or neuter: अर्धर्चः/अर्धर्चम् 'half verse', गोमयः/गोमयम् 'cowdung', पद्मः 'treasure'/पद्मम् 'lotus', धर्मः/धर्मम्.
24032: इदम् in anaphoric use (anvādeśa) becomes अश् (anudātta) before instrumental onwards: एतयोः छात्रयोः... अथो अनयोः 'these two students... and of them'.
24033: एतद् in anaphoric use becomes अश् before त्र and तस्, which also become anudātta: एतस्मिन्... अथो अत्र 'in this... and here', एतस्मात्... अथो अतः 'from this... and hence'.
24034: इदम्/एतद् in anaphoric use becomes एन् (anudātta) before accusative, instrumental singular, or locative dual: इमम्... अथो एनम्, अनेन... अथो एनेन.
24035: The phrase 'when ārdhadhātuka' governs sūtras through 2.4.58. Substitutions apply to ārdhadhātuka class (like āśīrliṅ), not sārvadhātuka (like vidhiliṅ): वध्यात् (benedictive) vs. हन्यात् (potential).
24036: अद् 'eat' becomes जग्धि before ल्यप् or कित् ārdhadhātuka starting with त्: प्रजग्ध्य 'having eaten', जग्ध 'eaten'. The इ is for articulation, not anubandha.
24037: अद् 'eat' becomes घस्लृ before लुङ् (aorist) and सन् (desiderative): अघसत् 'ate', जिघत्सति 'wishes to eat'. The लृ indicates अङ् for aorist.
24038: अद् 'eat' becomes घस्लृ before घञ् and अप्: घासः 'food/grass', प्रघसः 'voracity'.
24039: In Vedas, घस् diversely replaces अद्: घस्तान्नूनम्, सग्धिश्चने. Sometimes not: आदामद्य.
24040: Before लिट् (perfect), अद् optionally becomes घस्: जक्षुः or आदुः 'they ate'. Form: घस् + अतुस् → जघस् → जक्षतुः.
24041: Before लिट्, वेञ् 'weave' optionally becomes वय्: ववौ or उवाय 'wove'. With वय्: ऊयतुः/ऊवतुः 'they two wove'.
24042: हन् 'kill' becomes वध् before āśīrliṅ (benedictive): वध्यात् 'may he kill'. The zero-substitute is sthānivat, blocking vṛddhi in aorist अवधीत्.
24043: हन् becomes वध् before लुङ् (aorist): अवधीत् 'killed', अवधीष्टाम्.
24044: Before ātmanepada aorist, हन् optionally becomes वध्: अवधिष्ट or अहत, अवधिषाताम् or अहसाताम्.
24045: इण् 'go' becomes गा before लुङ्: अगात् 'went', अगाताम्, अगुः. Also इक् 'remember': अध्यगात् 'remembered'.
24046: इण् 'go' becomes गामि before णि (causal) when meaning 'going' (not 'informing'): गमयति 'makes go'. But प्रत्याययति 'causes to believe'.
24047: इण् 'go' becomes गमि before सन् when meaning 'going': जिगमिषति 'wishes to go'. But प्रतीषिषति 'wishes to inform'.
24048: इङ् 'study' becomes गमि before सन्: अधिजिगांसते 'wishes to study'. Always ātmanepada with अधि.
24049: इङ् 'study' becomes गाङ् before लिट्: अधिजगे 'studied', अधिजगाते, अधिजगिरे.
24050: इङ् optionally becomes गाङ् before लुङ् and लृङ्: अध्यगीष्ट or अध्यैष्ट, अध्यगीष्यत or अध्यैष्यत.
24051: इङ् optionally becomes गाङ् in causal + सन् or चङ्: अधिजिगापयिषति or अध्यापिपयिषति, अध्यजीगपत् or अध्यापिपत्.
24052: अस् 'be' becomes भू before ārdhadhātuka affixes: भविता 'will be', भवितुम्, भवितव्यम्. Perfect बभूव. Exception: as auxiliary, अस् keeps regular लिट् (आस, आसतुः).
24053: ब्रू 'speak' becomes वचि before ārdhadhātuka: वक्ता 'will speak', वक्तुम्. Perfect ऊचे (ātm.), वक्ष्यते 'will speak'.
24054: चक्ष् 'speak' becomes ख्या before ārdhadhātuka: ख्याता, ख्यातुम्. The इ of ख्यायि is for articulation.
24055: ग्रह् 'seize' becomes गृही before ārdhadhātuka: ग्रहीता 'will seize', ग्रहीतुम्. The इ prevents samprasāraṇa.
24056: ज्या 'overpower' becomes जि before ārdhadhātuka: जेता 'will conquer', जेतुम्, जित 'conquered'.
24057: व्ये 'cover' becomes वि before ārdhadhātuka: विता 'will cover', वितुम्, वीत 'covered'.
24058: प्सा 'eat' becomes सि before ārdhadhātuka: सीता 'will eat', सितुम्.
24059: वद् 'speak' becomes ब्रू before णि (causal): ब्रावयति 'makes speak'. The ऊ is lengthened.
24060: श्यि 'coagulate' is replaced by श्य before सन्: शिश्यासते 'wishes to coagulate'.
24061: चि 'gather' becomes चय् before सन् when preceded by वि or परि: विचिकीषते/विचिचयिषते 'wishes to collect'.
24062: हन् 'kill' becomes वध before the kṛt-affix घ: वधो जायते 'slaughter occurs'. Not with other affixes: हनिष्यति.
24063: गमि is substituted for अधि + इङ् before णि (causal): अधिगमयति 'teaches'. Also desiderative causal: अधिजिगमयिषति.
24064: स्था 'stand' becomes तिष्ठ् before the affix अ of present: तिष्ठति 'stands'. This blocks regular शप्.
24065: इण्, दधातृ-class, and ञिइण्धी become इ, धा, इन्ध् by lopa of final: एति 'goes', दधाति 'places', इन्धे 'kindles'.
24066: Verbs of 2nd class (अद्-class) don't take शप्: अत्ति 'eats', हन्ति 'kills'. The vikaraṇa is zero.
24067: जुहोत्यादि verbs (3rd class) don't take शप्—they reduplicate: जुहोति 'offers', बिभर्ति 'bears', दधाति 'places'.
24068: ह्वा 'call' and वा 'blow' become हू/ऊ before sārvadhātuka: जुहूषति (desid.), ऊति 'blows'.
24069: अज् 'drive' becomes वी before śap and sārvadhātuka: वियन्ति 'they drive'. Otherwise regular: अजति.
24070: Before णि (causal), वा 'weave' optionally becomes वय्: वापयति or वाययति 'makes weave'.
24071: लिट् (perfect) affixes are elided after हन् when meaning 'injury': जघान → जघ्नौ, जघ्नतुः, जघ्नुः.
24072: After वस् 'dwell', लिट् personal endings are elided and replaced by आम्+auxiliary: उवास or वसाञ्चकार, ऊषतुः, ऊषुः.
24073: लिट् affixes are elided by श्लु after roots ending in ārdhadhātuka-formed आम्: कासाञ्चक्रे 'coughed', चोरयामास 'stole'.
24074: लिट् affixes are elided after roots with आम् when initial इच् vowel is heavy: ईहाञ्चक्रे 'tried', ऊहाञ्चक्रे 'guessed'. Exception: ऋच्छ् forms आनर्च्छ.
24075: After दय्, अय्, आस्, लिट् takes आम्: दयाञ्चके 'gave', आसाञ्चक्रे 'sat'.
24076: After उष्, विद्, जागृ, आम् is optional in लिट्: ओषाञ्चकार or उवोष, विदाञ्चकार or विवेद.
24077: After भी, ह्री, भृ, हु, आम् is optional with श्लु-like treatment: विभयाञ्चकार or विभाय, जुहवाञ्चकार or जुहाव.
24078: After आम्-ending verb stems, कृ/भू/अस् auxiliaries are added: पाचयाञ्चकार, पाचयाम्बभूव, पाचयामास.
24079: The form विदाङ्कुर्वन्तु is irregular for विद् in imperative: विदाङ्कुर्वन्तु or विदन्तु 'let them know'.
24080: Vedic irregulars: अभ्युत्सादयामकः (causal aorist of सद्), पावयाङ्क्रियात् (potential causal of पू), विदामक्रन् (aorist of विद्).
24081: च्लि is added after roots before लुङ् (aorist). The actual substitute is सिच् or others specified below.
24082: सिच् replaces च्लि: अकार्षीत् 'did'. Optional with स्पृश्, मृश्, कृष्, तृप्, दृप्: अस्प्राक्षीत्/अस्पार्क्षीत्/अस्पृक्षत्.
24083: क्स replaces च्लि after शल्-final roots with इक् penultimate, not taking इट्: अधुक्षत् 'milked', अलिक्षत् 'licked'.
24084: क्स replaces च्लि after श्लिष् when meaning 'embrace': आश्लिक्षत् कन्याम्. Not joining: समाश्लिषत्.
24085: क्स doesn't replace च्लि after दृश्—it takes अङ् and सिच्: अदर्शत् or अद्राक्षीत् 'saw'.
31001: Adhikāra: 'pratyaya' (affix). From here through Book 5, what is taught (except base, upapada, upadhi, substitute, augment) is called pratyaya: कर्तव्यम्, करणीयम्.
31002: Adhikāra: 'and subsequent'. Affixes come after the root or prātipadika: कर्तव्यम् (after कृ), तैत्तिरीयम् (after तित्तिरि).
31003: An affix has udātta on its first vowel: कर्तव्यम् (accent on त). Exceptions: indicatory च् (final udātta), र् (middle), प् (anudātta), ञ् (preceding), क् (final for taddhita).
31004: Case affixes (सुप्) and पित् affixes are anudātta: दृषदौ, पचति (तिप् is पित्).
31005: सन् comes after गुप्/तिज्/कित् with meanings 'despise/endure/heal': जुगुप्सते 'despises', तितिक्षते 'endures', चिकित्सते 'heals'. Not with original meanings.
31006: सन् with long ई reduplication after मान्/बध्/दान्/शान्: मीमांसते 'investigates', बीभत्सते 'loathes'. Optional: मानयति also valid.
31007: सन् optionally after a root expressing the wished object, same agent: कर्तुमिच्छति = चिकीर्षति 'wishes to do'. Not different agents: देवदत्तस्य भोजनमिच्छति यज्ञदत्तः.
31008: क्यच् optionally for wishing one's own object: पुत्रमिच्छति = पुत्रीयति 'wishes for a son'. Not for others: राज्ञः पुत्रमिच्छति.
31009: काम्यच् also for wishing: पुत्रकाम्यति 'wishes for a son'.
31010: क्यच् optionally for treating-as: पुत्रमिवाचरति छात्रम् = पुत्रीयति छात्रम् 'treats student as son'.
31011: क्यङ् for behaving-like (agent comparison), eliding final स्: श्येनायते 'behaves like hawk', अप्सरायते. पयस्यते or पयायते.
31012: क्यङ् for becoming (अभूततद्भाव) after भृश-class (not taking च्वि): भृशायते 'becomes much', शीघ्रायते 'becomes swift'. Final consonant elided.
31013: क्यष् for becoming after लोहित-class and डाच्-ending words: लोहितायते/लोहितायति 'becomes red', पटपटायते 'makes patapata sound'.
31014: क्यङ् for exerting in evil after कष्ट with dative: कष्टाय क्रामति = कष्टायते 'plots mischief'. Also सत्र, कक्ष, कृच्छ्र, गहन.
31015: क्यङ् after रोमन्थ (ruminating) and तपस् (austerity): रोमन्थायते गौः 'cow ruminates', तपस्यति 'performs austerity' (parasmaipada).
31016: क्यङ् for ejecting after वाष्प/ऊष्म: बाष्पायते 'emits vapor', उष्मायते 'emits heat', फेनायते 'froths'.
31017: क्यङ् for making after शब्द/वैर/कलह/अभ्र/कण्व/मेघ: शब्दायते 'makes noise', वैरायते, कलहायते. Also सुदिन, दुर्दिन, नीहार.
31018: क्यङ् for feeling after सुख-class when agent experiences: सुखायते 'feels pleasure', दुःखायते. Not others' feelings.
31019: Affixes for making after नमस्/वरिवस्/चित्रङ्: नमस्यति देवान् 'worships gods', वरिवस्यति गुरून् 'serves elders', चित्रीयते 'astonishes'.
31020: णिङ् for making after पुच्छ/भाण्ड/चीवर: उत्पुच्छयते 'lifts tail', सम्भाण्डायते 'collects pots', सञ्चीवरायते 'collects rags'.
31021: णिच् for making after मुण्ड/मिश्र/श्लक्ष्ण/लवण/व्रत/वस्त्र/हल/कल/कृत/तूस्त: मुण्डयति 'shaves', मिश्रयति 'mixes', लवणयति 'salts'. Also curādi verbs: चोरयति.
31022: यङ् for repetition/intensity after monosyllabic consonant-initial roots: पापच्यते 'cooks repeatedly', जाज्वल्यते 'shines intensely'. Not after upasarga or vowel-initial.
31023: यङ् invariably means crookedness after motion verbs: चङ्क्रम्यते 'moves crookedly'. For intensity, use phrase: भृशं क्रामति.
31024: यङ् invariably for contempt (भावगर्हा) after लुप्/सद्/चर्/जप्/जभ्/दह्/दश्/गॄ: लोलुप्यते 'cuts badly', जञ्जप्यते 'recites badly'.
31025: णिच् after सत्याप/पाश/रूप/वीणा/तूल/श्लोक/सेना/लोम/त्वच/वर्म/वर्ण/चूर्ण and curādi: सत्यापयति, विपाशयति 'unfetters', वर्णयति 'describes'.
31026: णिच् forms causatives (हेतुमत्): कटं कारयति 'causes mat to be made', ओदनं पाचयति 'has rice cooked'.
31027: यक् after कण्डू-class roots: कण्डूयति/कण्डूयते 'itches', मन्तूयति, सुखयति, दुःखयति.
31028: आय after गुप्/धूप्/विच्छ्/पण्/पन्: गोपायति 'protects', धूपायति 'heats', पणायति 'praises'. पण् with 'contract' sense doesn't take आय.
31029: ईयङ् after ऋति: ऋतीयते 'reproaches'. Always ātmanepada (ङ्).
31030: णिङ् after कम्: कामयते 'desires'. ण् causes vṛddhi, ङ् ātmanepada.
31031: आय/ईयङ्/णिङ् optional before ārdhadhātuka: गोपायिता or गोप्ता, कामयिता or कमिता.
31032: Roots formed by सन् etc. are themselves called dhātu: चिकीर्षा, कारि, चेक्रिय are independent roots taking शप् etc.
31033: स्य before लृ (लृट्/लृङ्), तासि before लुट्: करिष्यति (future), अकरिष्यत् (conditional), कर्ता (periphrastic future). इ in तासि prevents nasal loss: मन्ता.
31034: सिप् diversely in Vedas before लेट् (subjunctive): जोषिषत्, तारिषत्. Sometimes not: पताति.
31035: आम् before लिट् for कास् and derivative verbs (periphrastic perfect): कासाञ्चक्रे 'coughed', चोरयामास 'stole'. Not Vedic: कृष्णो नोनाव.
31036: आम् before लिट् for roots beginning with heavy इच्-vowel (except ऋच्छ्): ईहाञ्चक्रे 'tried', ऊहाञ्चक्रे 'guessed'. Exception: आनर्च्छ.
31037: आम् before लिट् after दय्/अय्/आस्: दयाञ्चके 'gave', पलायाञ्चक्रे 'fled', आसाञ्चक्रे 'sat'.
31038: आम् optional before लिट् after उष्/विद्/जागृ: ओषाञ्चकार or उवोष, विदाञ्चकार or विवेद, जागराञ्चकार or जजागार.
31039: आम् optional with श्लु-effect after भी/ह्री/भृ/हु: विभयाञ्चकार or विभाय, जुहवाञ्चकार or जुहाव.
31040: After आम्-ending stems, कृ/भू/अस् auxiliaries follow for लिट्: पाचयाञ्चकार, पाचयाम्बभूव, पाचयामास.
31041: विदाङ्कुर्वन्तु irregular for विद् + imperative: विदाङ्कुर्वन्तु or विदन्तु 'let them know'. All persons/numbers possible.
31042: Vedic irregulars: अभ्युत्सादयामकः, प्रजनयामकः, चिकयामकः, रमयामकः, पावयाङ्क्रियात्, विदामक्रन्.
31043: च्लि after roots before लुङ् (aorist). The इ for articulation, च् for accent. Replaced by सिच् etc.
31044: सिच् replaces च्लि: अकार्षीत् 'did'. Optional with स्पृश्/मृश्/कृष्/तृप्/दृप्: अस्प्राक्षीत्, अस्पार्क्षीत्, or अस्पृक्षत्.
31045: क्स replaces च्लि after शल्-final roots with इक् penultimate, not taking इट्: अधुक्षत् 'milked', अलिक्षत् 'licked'.
31046: क्स after श्लिष् meaning 'embrace': आश्लिक्षत् कन्याम्. Not joining: समाश्लिषत्.
31047: क्स not after दृश्—it takes अङ् and सिच्: अदर्शत् or अद्राक्षीत् 'saw'.
31048: चङ् replaces च्लि after णि-ending verbs, श्रि/द्रु/स्रु for agent-denoting aorist: अचीकरत् 'caused to make', अशिश्रियत् 'served', अदुद्रुवत् 'ran'.
31049: चङ् optional after धे/श्वि: अदधत् or अधात्/अधासीत्; अशिश्वियत् or अश्वत्/अश्वयीत्.
31050: चङ् optional in Vedas after गुप् (not taking आय): अजुगुपतम्. Classical: अगौप्तम्, अगोपिष्टम्.
31051: चङ् not used in Vedas for causatives of ऊन्/ध्वन्/इल्/अर्द्: ऊनयीः (Vedic), औनिनत् (classical).
31052: अङ् replaces च्लि after अस्/वच्/ख्या for agent: पर्यास्थत, अवोचत्, आख्यत्.
31053: अङ् after लिप्/सिच्/ह्वे for agent: अलिपत् 'painted', असिचत् 'sprinkled', आह्वत् 'called'.
31054: अङ् optional after लिप्/सिच्/ह्वे with ātmanepada: अलिपत or अलिप्त, असिचत or असिक्त, आह्वत or आह्वास्त.
31055: अङ् after पुष्-class, द्युत्-class, and लृत् roots in parasmaipada: अपुषत् 'nourished', अद्युतत् 'shone', अगमत् 'went'.
31056: अङ् after सृ/शास्/ऋ in both padas: असरत् 'went', अशिषत् 'ordered', आरत् 'went', समरन्त.
31057: अङ् optional after इरित् roots in parasmaipada: अभिदत् or अभैत्सीत् (from भिद्). But अभित्त in ātmanepada.
31058: अङ् optional after जॄ/स्तम्भ्/म्रुच्/म्लुच्/ग्रुच्/ग्लुच्/ग्लुञ्च्/श्वि in parasmaipada: अजरत् or अजारीत्; अस्तम्भत् or अस्तम्भीत्.
31059: अङ् after कृ/मृ/दॄ/रुह् in Vedas: अकरत्, अमरत्, अदरत्, आरुहत्. Classical: अकार्षीत्, अमृत, अदारीत्, अरुक्षत्.
31060: चिण् after पद् when त follows (3rd sg. ātm.): अपादि 'went'. Dual/plural: अपसाताम्, अपत्सत.
31061: चिण् optional after दीप्/जन्/बुध्/पूर्/ताय्/प्याय् with 3rd sg. ātm.: अदीपि or अदीपिष्ट, अजनि or अजनिष्ट.
31062: चिण् optional in reflexive voice (कर्मकर्तरि) after vowel-final roots: अकारि कटः स्वयमेव or अकृत. Consonant-final: चिण् obligatory.
31063: चिण् optional for reflexive दुह्: अदोहि or अदुग्ध गौः स्वयमेव. Non-reflexive: चिण् compulsory.
31064: चिण् not for reflexive रुध्: अन्ववारुद्ध गौ स्वयमेव. Non-reflexive: अन्ववारोधि.
31065: चिण् not for तप् in remorse sense: अतप्त तपः, अन्वतप्त पापेन.
31066: चिण् for भाव (impersonal) or कर्मन् (passive): अशयि भवता 'you lay', अकारि कटो देवदत्तेन 'mat was made'.
31067: यक् after roots before sārvadhātuka for भाव/कर्मन्: आस्यते भवता (impersonal), क्रियते कटः (passive), क्रियते कटः स्वयमेव (reflexive).
31068: शप् after roots before sārvadhātuka for agent: भू + शप् + ति = भवति. For bhū-class and सन्-derived roots.
31069: श्यन् after divādi (4th class) roots for agent: दिव् + श्यन् = दीव्यति 'plays', सीव्यति 'sews'.
31070: श्यन् optional after भ्राश्/भ्लाश्/भ्रम्/क्रम्/क्लम्/त्रस्/त्रुट्/लष्: भ्रमति or भ्राम्यति 'whirls', क्रामति or क्राम्यति 'walks'.
31071: श्यन् optional after यस् without upasarga: यस्यति or यसति 'strives'. With upasarga: आयस्यति only.
31072: श्यन् optional after सम् + यस्: संयस्यति or संयसति.
31073: श्नु after svādi (5th class) roots for agent: सु + श्नु = सुनोति 'presses out'.
31074: शृ substitutes for श्रु before श्नु: श्रु → शृ + नु = शृणोति 'hears'.
31075: श्नु optional after अक्ष् 'pervade': अक्ष्णोति or अक्षति.
31076: श्नु optional after तक्ष् with wood: तक्षति or तक्ष्णोति काष्ठम् 'hews wood'. With speech: सन्तक्षति वाग्भिः only.
31077: श after tudādi (6th class) roots for agent: तुद + श = तुदति 'strikes'.
31078: श्नम् after rudhādi (7th class) roots, inserted after last vowel: रुध् + न = रुणद्धि 'obstructs', भिनत्ति 'splits'.
31079: उ after tanādi (8th class) and कृ for agent: तन् + उ = तनोति 'expands', कृ + उ = करोति 'makes'.
31080: उ after धिन्व/कृण्व with अ replacing final इ: धिन् + उ = धिनोति 'pleases'.
31081: श्ना after kryādi (9th class) for agent: क्री + श्ना = क्रीणाति 'buys', प्रीणाति 'pleases'.
31082: श्ना or श्नु after स्तम्भ्/स्तुम्भ्/स्कम्भ्/स्कुम्भ्/स्कु: स्तभ्नाति or स्तभ्नोति, स्कुनाति or स्कुनोति.
31083: शानच् replaces श्ना after consonant-final root + हि: पुषाण 'nourish!', गृहाण 'take!'. Vowel-final: क्रीणीहि.
31084: शायच् also in Vedas: गृभाय. शानच् also used: बधान.
31085: In Vedas, vikaraṇas interchange diversely: भेदति (instead of भिनत्ति), मरते (instead of म्रियते), two vikaraṇas: नेषतु, तरुषेम.
31086: अङ् in Vedas before āśīrliṅ for स्था/गा/गम्/वच्/वद्/शक्/रुह्: उपस्थेयम्, गमेम, वोचेम, शकेयम्.
31087: When action affects agent like object (कर्मवद्भाव/reflexive): भिद्यते काष्ठं स्वयमेव 'wood splits itself'. यक् and ātmanepada apply.
31088: तप् takes कर्मवद्भाव only with तपस्: तप्यते तपस्तापसः. Not: उत्तपति सुवर्णम्.
31089: यक्/चिण् not for reflexive दुह्/स्नु/नम्: दुग्धे, प्रस्नुते, नमते. Also not for णि-verbs, श्रन्थ्/मन्थ्/ब्रू.
31090: श्यन् optional for reflexive कुष्/रञ्ज् (Eastern view) with parasmaipada: कुष्यति or कुष्यते, रज्यति or रज्यते.
31091: Adhikāra: 'after verbal roots' applies through end of Book 3.
31092: A word in locative in the sūtras means upapada: कर्मणि (locative) → the accusative word is upapada. कुम्भकारः 'potter' (कुम्भम् is upapada).
31093: Any affix (except tiṅ) after a root is called kṛt: कृ + तव्य = कर्तव्यम्. Forms prātipadikas.
31094: A special kṛt optionally debars a general one (if different form). Same form: special debars. विक्षिपः (क) or विक्षेपकः (ण्वुल्). Not for strī affixes.
31095: Adhikāra: 'kṛtya' for sūtras 95-133. These are potential passive participles (gerundives).
31096: तव्यत्/तव्य/अनीयर् after all roots: कर्तव्यम्, करणीयम् 'to be done'. Vartt: केलिमर् also: पचेलिमा माषाः.
31097: यत् after vowel-final roots: गेयम् 'to be sung', पेयम् 'to be drunk'. Vartt: also तक्/शच्/चत्/यत्/जन्. वध्यम् or घात्यम् from हन्.
31098: यत् after labial-final with penultimate अ: शप्यम् 'to be cursed', लभ्यम् 'obtainable'. Others: पाक्यम् (पच्).
31100: यत् after गद्/मद्/चर्/यम् without upasarga: गद्यम् 'prose', मद्यम् 'wine', चर्यम् 'conduct'. With upasarga: प्रगाद्यम् (ण्यत्).
31101: Irregulars: अवद्यम् 'condemnable', पण्यम् 'saleable', वर्या 'bride choosing husband'. Regular forms also exist.
31102: वह्यम् 'vehicle' irregular: वह्यं शकटम्. For 'ox': वाह्यः (ण्यत्).
